Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Ultrahigh Performance Liquid Chromatography Instrument to Improve the Quality and Scope of Research at Valparaiso University and Collaborating Institutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, Valparaiso University will acquire a a ultrahigh performance liquid chromatography system with four detectors. The instrument is approriate for analyzing samples by separating the components using chromatography techniques. This award has an environmental and biochemical research focus. The environmental research is directed at water analysis. One of the projects involves water quality studies of Lake Michigan watershed surface waters. The research will involve collaborations with The Northwest Indiana Cluster of GLISTEN (Great Lakes Innovative Stewardship through Education Network). This is a network of local undergraduate institutions, K-12 schools, and environmental community partners that collaborate to integrate curriculum, stewardship, and research to protect the health of the Great Lakes watershed. GLISTEN includes Ivy Tech Community College and Cal State Long Beach, with many students from underrepresented groups including African American students at the former and Hispanic students at the latter.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research, especially in areas such as (a) assesing water quality of Lake Michigan watershed surface waters; (b) studying oxidative remediation of organic contaminants in waste waters and transformations of organic compounds in surface water; and (c) assessing storm-water treatment technologies for pollution reduction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The acquisition of an ultra-high performance liquid chromatography instrument (UHPLC) equipped with multiple detectors, including a mass spectrometer, has enhanced research activities and increased collaborative work in the Valparaiso University science and engineering departments. Many undergraduate research students from Valparaiso University, Indiana University Northwest and Ivy Tech Community College have been trained to run samples and analyze data. Chemistry faculty have designed projects and experiments for upper level chemistry courses that utilized the data collection capacity of the instrument. Additionally, the instrument has been used in environmental education and other science-based projects involving local, young students to demonstrate the capacity of technology in the science fields. Interesting and innovative radiation chemistry projects were made possible with the UHPLC. These included the probing of the viability of amino acids under extraterrestrial environments, evaluating ligand stability for use in nuclear waste clean-up and determining the effectiveness of radicals in the degradation of problematic perfluorinated compounds. The instrument has been used by faculty and undergraduate researchers in the VU Chemistry Department in the analysis of synthetic organic reaction products and natural materials’ extractions.

When liquid chromatography was connected with the instrument’s conductivity detector, projects that required critical analysis of ions were made possible.  The quantification of chloride, nitrate and sulfate elevated the scientific analysis of surface water quality monitoring, which was done in partnership with local middle school students and teachers. As part of a study to understand the formation of dune decomposition chimneys in the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, rainwater samples were analyzed for calcium and magnesium ions. These projects are long-term and ongoing. The data from the watershed monitoring is expected to be available to the public soon and ongoing data collections will be continually added to the database.      

The instrument acquisition has cultivated productive collaborations and the possibility for many more in the upcoming years. Projects with Idaho National Labs, the United States Geological Survey and other non-local universities (California State, Florida International, University of Notre Dame, and University of Minnesota) have been carried out, planned or discussed.  The data generated from the UHPLC have been part of numerous conference and research presentations and publications. As part of Valparaiso University’s efforts to enhance research production, which include a new science building, the UHPLC is housed in a room for mass spectrometers and faculty continue to expand upon research prospects afforded by the instrument.
